content.description:
The north face of Sloan has been affected by climate change and ice retreat and is now in condition for a much shorter window than at the time of the first ascent. Approach as per the northeast ridge but traverse west to reach the glacier below the face. Cross the bergschrund near the center of the face, then climb steep snow gullies (60 degree plus) and snice plastered over sloping granite, as well as 4th class rock bands, directly to the summit ridge, topping out slightly east of the summit. The first ascensionist compared the exposure to the Kain Face on Robson.



From northeast ridge, either traverse west through forest to the toe of the glacier, or climb to the first notch on the ridge and downclimb a 3rd class snow gully to reach the glacier partway up

Flukes, pins and ice screws? FA was soloed and there have been few if any repeats.

The long northeast ridge. Begin from the upper logging road (if descending the south side, best o park where the two roads fork) and follow game and climber trails through forest along the ridge crest. Where you break out into the alpine, the gradient steepens and scrambling begins. Climb towards a notch visible on the ridge crest, either climbing through it, or passing it on the left. Traverse the ridge line beyond (3rd class) until you reach a narrow, steep gap. Downclimb into the gap, exposed but good holds, and climb out the far side (4th class, some feel it's low 5th). Continue (more 3rd class) along the ridge line to the final summit tower, which is most easily climbed moving right and circling around to the north side. A low-angle wide crack is a prominent feature of this final section. 



Follow the upper logging spur to its end, then progress through the forest along the ridge crest.

If descending the south gully, head west along the ridge from the summit. Pass one gully and descend into the second one you encounter. Descend this one to the moraines, follow moraine down to Upper Ault Lake, and descend heather and pumice slopes to Ault Creek. Follow trail along Ault Creek and past Lower Ault Lake back to the logging roads.

Easy to place trad gear or sling horns for pro if required.

Approach as per the north face, but once on the glacier, cross over to the right hand (northwest) ridge. Follow it easily to the summit over 3rd class rock and moderately steep snow just left of the ridge crest. Best early in the season; probably just 3rd class rock late in the season



From lower northeast ridge, bushwack through forest to reach the toe of the glacier. Diagonal up and right, passing under the north face, to reach the ridge near two small towers.

Two tools are nice to have for some of the snow bulges; can be done with a single ice axe but less secure.

This line climbs the rib immediately right of the most commonly climbed south gully. It is distinguished by a steep white headwall partway up, with distinctly visible X cracks, which the route avoids to the left. Start up a clean white arete for 1 pitch, then climb a short wall to a ledge, and the featured slabby face to the left of a chimney. The fourth pitch turns the white wall to the left by circling around the arete, climbing into a slabby bay, and stemming up a wide crack at the back of the bay (5.9 crux). Climb a low-angle pitch on the ridge crest, then steep juggy flakes on the final tower. From the top of the roped climbing, several hundred feet of 3rd and 4th class scrambling lead to the summit ridge.

Pitch by pitch:Â 

Pitch 1: Beginning right on the arete bounding the gully right of the standard gully, climb cracks and arete to a large ledge (30m, 5.7). Move belay 15m across ledge to next wall.

P2: Climb large corner, avoiding greenery via face climbing up featured right wall. Good horizontal cracks for gear. Belay on ledge above (55m, 5.7)

P3: Cut back left and pull short bulge to gain hanging slab left of corner. Climb slab to arete, then go right and up short overhanging stemming corner to belay above on arete with many blocks (35m, 5.8)

P4: Move belay 30m along low angle arete to base of vertical white wall (30m, Class 3)

P5: Move left and climb arete on good holds but poor pro (small wires behind flakes) for 10m or so until able to stem left to corner system. Continue up to ledge below second white wall. Climb right-hand vertical corner (awkward at first, then good stemming) to belay above (40m, 5.9)

P6: Move right into large corner/ramp, climb to its end (60m, 5.1)

P7: Climb wall left of arete up flakes and blocks, finishing right of fresh rockfall scar. Inobvious route finding but good pro. (45m, 5.7)

From here, 250m of scrambling reaches the summit - either the lower-angle ridge crest or the gully immediately to the right can be used.



Just right of the standard gully start

Standard Squamish rack to 3.5"

climbs.name: South Gullies
climbs.fa: FRA: C. Fenner, B. Hardie, T. Pollard, G. Tanner, T. Waldon 1949; probably climbed earlier by both First Nations and prospectors.

content.description:
Five separate gullies run to the summit ridge of Sloan from the basin to the southeast. The most commonly used one, which is third class, is second from left as you count across the face, and which is hidden until you are almost below it. The crux of this gully is a steep 10 m high wall at its mouth. Above, climb snow and scree to reach the summit ridge west of the summit. On descent, this is the second gully you reach when traversing west along the ridge from the summit. The other four gullies have also all been climbed, but are more difficult, with more loose rock because they are less travelled, and climbing that pushes into 4th class territory.



From upper Ault Lake, hike up the moraine on the right side of the cirque, below Sloan's south face, and traverse the moraine crest westward until directly below the route.

Scrambling. Crampons may be required in early season when there is snow in the gully.

climbs.name: Southeast ridge
climbs.fa: D. Anderson, S. Coombes, R. Fabiche, P. Jordan, 1984

content.description:
Climb the long rib to the left of Dragon Couloir, the fifth from left (and largest) gully dropping down the south face of Sloan, in this case from the gap on the northeast ridge. The rib is mostly 3rd and 4th class climbing with a single pitch of mid-5th near half height. Over the years, this route has been a popular fall ascent for large BCMC parties.



From Upper Ault Lake, ascend more or less directly towards Dragon Couloir, then trend left to the toe of the rib.

A light rack to 3" is more than sufficient for the 5th class pitch. Originally done with nuts and hexes, and that's still a sufficient rack if you want to go light.

Climb the white buttress to the left of the most commonly used South Gully. Five pitches of moderate 5th class (5.4 to 5.7) with the crux, a short 5.8 wall, on the third pitch. The climb tops out on the southwest ridge, which is easily followed to the summit.

Pitch by pitch:

1) Start near a small pinnacle and scramble up the rubble ramp between the pinnacle and the main buttress to about 15m below the pinnacle col. From here w 40m or so up cracks and face holds, low-5th, to a ledge

2) Wide crack and flakes off the ledge, 5.7

3) Scrambling, then a long 5.6 pitch (bit of simulclimbing, total length around 90 m) to a nice ledge.

4) Crux: two 5.8 chimney moves to start, then nice hand-sized flakes, a short wall and a black-lichened ramp, a full pitch (60m)Â 

5) Move belay 10 m, to a nice ledge on the buttress crest then a full pitch (~50 m) of 5.5 climbing

Continue up a few hundred meters of Class 2-3 scrambling to the summit



Begin up scrambling towards an obvious fist crack on the right side of the buttress and continue along the edge of steeper white rock to reach the buttress crest

Standard Squamish rack to 3.5"
Highest peak in the Sloan Group, this granite summit overlooks the Bridge River Valley and Hurley FSR. Climbs range from 3rd class gully scrambles to technical buttresses and a steep mixed face.
